docs.lead_paragraph: New York State’s acting labor commissioner, with support from Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, ordered the raise to go into effect at the end of the year.

headline.main: Minimum Wage for New York City’s Tipped Workers Will Increase to $7.50
headline.print_headline: Minimum Wage for City’s Tipped Workers Will Increase to $7.50

docs.abstract: New York Gov Andrew M Cuomo announces raise in minimum wage for New York City's tipped workers to $7.50 per hour; rejects Mayor Bill de Blasio's proposal of $13 per hour minimum; increase will take affect at end of 2015.
docs.snippet: New York State’s acting labor commissioner, with support from Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, ordered the raise to go into effect at the end of the year.

docs.lead_paragraph: The secretary of health and human services said in a letter to Congress that a court decision against the administration would do “massive damage.”

headline.main: Congress Is Told Ruling Against Health Law Would Impact Poor
headline.print_headline: Congress Is Told Administration Has No Remedy for a Ruling Against Health Law

docs.abstract: Obama administration tells Congress it has no plan in place to help those affected if Supreme Court votes to cut off health insurance subsidies in several states, placing responsibility squarely on shoulders of Republican lawmakers.
docs.snippet: The secretary of health and human services said in a letter to Congress that a court decision against the administration would do “massive damage.”

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: Millions would lose their insurance, and Sylvia Mathews Burwell said there was little the administration could do to soften the blow.

headline.main: Health Secretary Says There’s No Backup Plan if Supreme Court Rules Against Law

docs.snippet: Millions would lose their insurance, and Sylvia Mathews Burwell said there was little the administration could do to soften the blow.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Treasury Department said those who expected to pay less taxes after receiving corrected health insurance data could amend their filings, but it would not be mandatory.

headline.main: Erroneous HealthCare.gov Tax Forms Will Not Force Taxpayers to Resubmit Returns
headline.print_headline: Tax Form Error Will Not Force Resubmissions

docs.abstract: Treasury Dept announces that roughly 50,000 taxpayers who already filed returns based on inaccurate data sent by HealthCare.gov will not have to refile; those affected will, however, be able to submit new returns if they expect updated data to generate a larger refund.
docs.snippet: The Treasury Department said those who expected to pay less taxes after receiving corrected health insurance data could amend their filings, but it would not be mandatory.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Obama administration has no way to repair the damage that would result from a Supreme Court decision against Obamacare that would make health care unaffordable for millions of Americans, a top health adviser said on Tuesday.

headline.main: U.S. Health Official Says No Fix if Obamacare Subsidies Thrown Out
headline.print_headline: U.S. Health Official Says No Fix if Obamacare Subsidies Thrown Out

docs.snippet: The Obama administration has no way to repair the damage that would result from a Supreme Court decision against Obamacare that would make health care unaffordable for millions of Americans, a top health adviser said on Tuesday.

docs.lead_paragraph: President Barack Obama's health secretary told Congress Tuesday that she has no administrative actions available to fix the "massive damage to our health care system" that would result should the Supreme Court invalidate federal subsidies that help millions of Americans buy health care coverage.

headline.main: Administration: No Quick Fix if Court Kills Health Subsidies

docs.lead_paragraph: Taxpayers who've filed their 2014 returns only to learn that the government provided them with erroneous information on health care subsidies won't be required to submit corrected returns, the Treasury Department said Tuesday.

headline.main: Treasury Issues Reprieve for Health Law Tax Errors
headline.print_headline: Treasury Issues Reprieve for Health Law Tax Errors

docs.snippet: Taxpayers who've filed their 2014 returns only to learn that the government provided them with erroneous information on health care subsidies won't be required to submit corrected returns, the Treasury Department said Tuesday.

docs.lead_paragraph: Health insurer Anthem Inc, which earlier this month reported that it was hit by a massive cyberbreach, said on Tuesday that 8.8 million to 18.8 million people who were members of other Blue Cross Blue Shield plans could be victims in the attack.

headline.main: Anthem Says Hack May Affect More Than 8.8 Million Other BCBS Members
headline.print_headline: Anthem Says Hack May Affect More Than 8.8 Million Other BCBS Members

docs.snippet: Health insurer Anthem Inc, which earlier this month reported that it was hit by a massive cyberbreach, said on Tuesday that 8.8 million to 18.8 million people who were members of other Blue Cross Blue Shield plans could be victims in the attack.

docs.lead_paragraph: Budget cuts forced the IRS to reduce the number of tax audits last year to the lowest level in a decade, IRS Commissioner John Koskinen said Tuesday. And the number of audits could be even lower this year.

headline.main: IRS: Your Chances of Getting Audited Lowest in a Decade
headline.print_headline: IRS: Your Chances of Getting Audited Lowest in a Decade

docs.snippet: Budget cuts forced the IRS to reduce the number of tax audits last year to the lowest level in a decade, IRS Commissioner John Koskinen said Tuesday. And the number of audits could be even lower this year.
